comment.body:
> [saitama](#comment_1_1ATu1DyVH63v9TKZ8MGCQ61dLYpEVgBy9X): I not sure, I'm new here, but I think the ones that have clone option also have on the folder of the zerosite an "*/data-default" folder. I think that is to make ease for people to easily make a version of that site of there one.

That's right. But to allow people to clone, you also need to add `"cloneable": true,` to your content.json file.

> [acehigh](#comment_2_1Kg7CXZM5h3wTPENsTDwWUmRBf9VhYy2cW): But even then it is still possible to just go to your data folder and clone it manually, right?

Yes, that's right. The manual method needs one simple command to sign the data/users/content.json file. It's really easy. For more info go [here](http://127.0.0.1:43110/Blog.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Post:3:How+to+have+a+blog+like+this) :)

> one of the most important parts of ZeroNet is the ability to trust that a piece of content is generated/curated by a specific identity

Agreed! That's also a good reason to keep your Id well guarded. I made a post (mostly for fun) that takes care of that. Sadly it's limited to Linux and Mac users, [here it is](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1QLLPpowM6BWxKYKops1WkCafuFPhFBnAx/?Post:4:Changing+and+encrypting+ZeroIds).
Zeronet has a single developer, nofish. Apart from some minor fixes from other people, he's the real deal, **The One True Developer**. What an amazing world we live in.
